Kolmogorov‚ÄìSmirnov Test‚Ä¢

distance distribution

15 Apr 2020

Last modified on 01 Oct 2021.

  • What & Why?
  • How?
  • Code?
  • References

What & Why?

To check the similar distribution of 2 samples drawn from population. If these samples are normal, we can use T-test, but if they are not normal, we need to use KS-test. KS-test is a non-parametric test.

Null hypothesis (H0H_0H0‚Äã): ‚ÄúTwo samples drawn from population with the same distribution.‚Äù

üëâ Read more about p-value. We use this value to evaluate the true/false of above null hypothesis.

The difference (in use) of T-test (need an assumption of nomality) and KS-test (don‚Äôt need),

  • Two samples have the same mean & standard deviation ‚áí p-value is high ‚áí cannot reject H0H_0H0‚Äã (not true)
  • KS-test can detect the variance ‚áí p-value is low ‚áí we can reject H0H_0H0‚Äã ‚áí 2 samples are not the same distribution!!! (yep!)

How?

If the KS statistic is small or the p-value is high, then we cannot reject the hypothesis that the distributions of the two samples are the same.

Code?

from scipy import stats

# one-sample KS test
stats.kstest(x, 'norm')

# two-sample KS test
stats.ks_2samp(x, y)

References

  • Matthew E. Clapham ‚Äì 10: Kolmogorov-Smirnov test (video)
  • An example of why we need to use EMD instead of Kolmogorov‚ÄìSmirnov distance (video).
